citation.article-title: Methylopila capsulata gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel non-pigmented aerobic facultatively methylotrophic bacterium.

p.s: Description of Methylopila gen. nov.
Methylopila (Me.thyl.o.pi.la. M.L.n. methyl the methyl group; Gr. adj. pila ball or sphere; M.L. Methylopila methyl-using sphere)
When grown on methanol mineral salt medium, the cells are motile rods, usually 0.5-0.7 μm in diameter and 1.0-1.3 μm in length, which occur singly or in pairs.
Gram-negative.
Non-pigmented.
Endospores are absent.
Multiply by fission.
No prosthecae detected.
Colonies are white.
Pyocyanin and fluorescein are not produced.
Growth is supported by nutrient agar and PYG agar.
The methyl red and Voges-Proskauer tests are negative.
Oxidase- and urease-positive.
Acids are produced from sugars oxidatively, but not fermentatively.
Nitrates are reduced to nitrites slowly.
Chemo-organotrophic and facultatively methylotrophic assimilating C1 compounds by the isocitrate lyase-serine pathway.
Vitamins are not required for growth.
Ammonium salts, nitrate, urea, peptone, some amino acids and methylated amines are utilized as nitrogen sources.
Strictly aerobic, with respiratory metabolism.
Good growth occurs between pH 6.5 and 7.5, but not above pH 9.0 and below pH 5.0.
Grows well at 28 and 35°C but not at 42°C.
No growth in the presence of 3% NaCl.
The cell fatty acid profile is characterized by the presence of 60-70% cis-vaccenic acid (c18:1ω7).
The major hydroxy acid is 3-OH C14:0.
The quinone system is ubiquinone Q-10.
Dominant phospholipids are phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylcholine.
The DNA G + C content ranges from 66 to 70 mol %.
The levels of DNA-DNA hybridization with members of the genera Methylorhabdus, Methylobacterium, Aminobacter, Hyphomicrobium and Pseudomonas are less than 10%.

The genus Methylopila belongs to the α-2 subclass of the Proteobacteria, as revealed by comparative sequence analysis of the 16s rDNA, and is phylogenetically distinct from the other methylotrophic genera.
The type species is Methylopila capsulata.
